definition: to raise a tough question

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
difficult (to...)/problem/difficulty/difficult/not good
disaster/distress/to scold
surname Ti
topic/problem for discussion/exam question/subject/to inscribe/to mention/CL:個|个[ge4],道[dao4]

sentences.english: Don't be awkward: we have to get this finished by five o'clock.
sentences.chinese: 不要出难题了，我们必须赶五点钟前把这项工作干完。

sentences.english: They really put me through the mill in my interview.
sentences.chinese: 他们在面试时实在是给我出难题了。

sentences.english: Why didn't you ask difficult questions just now?
sentences.chinese: 那你们刚才怎么不出难题呢？

sentences.english: He tried to work out the problem.
You're always giving me big nuts to crack.
And I thought I would tease you with this one here.
sentences.chinese: 我又要给大家出难题了。

sentences.english: But I guess I like to make things difficult on myself, because I do that all the time.
sentences.chinese: 但我猜我喜欢给自己出难题，因为我一直这样做。

sentences.english: She know how to score off people who ask difficult question.
sentences.chinese: 她很会让那些给她出难题的人自讨没趣。

sentences.english: I hope the professor doesn't throw us any curveballs on the test.
sentences.chinese: 我希望教授考试的时候别给我们出难题。

sentences.english: Nationals to calm, to mutual understanding, not a problem to the Government.
sentences.chinese: 国民要冷静，要相互理解，不要给政府出难题。

definition: to look for trouble
lit. to make sb wear tight shoes (idiom)/to make life difficult for sb
to play dumb/to slack off (idiom)
(coll.) to cause trouble for sb/to inconvenience
(theater) to dismantle the stage/(fig.) to pull the rug out from under sb's feet/to undermine sb's plans
see 耍滑[shua3 hua2]
to make people feel even more stressed or annoyed (coll.)/to make traffic congestion even worse
to butter sb up/to try to impress sb
to be hard on sb/to deliberately make things difficult
to pick fault with/to spot the differences/to nitpick/to pick a quarrel/to find complaint with
to make a mess of sth
(coll.) to be the object of flattery/to be placed on a pedestal
to look for employment/to pick a quarrel
intentional/deliberate/on purpose
to create difficulties/to invite trouble/to be troublesome
to ask for trouble/to bring misfortune on oneself
